slides.title: Learning Objectives
slides.content:
By the end of this module, you will be able to:

  1. Apply basic geometric transformations (translation, rotation, scaling)
  2. Understand homogeneous coordinates and transformation matrices
  3. Implement affine and projective transformations
  4. Choose appropriate interpolation methods
  5. Perform image registration and alignment

slides.title: Basic Transformations
slides.content: Translation, rotation, and scaling

slides.title: Basic Geometric Transformations
slides.content: Translation, rotation, and scaling are the fundamental building blocks

slides.title: Rotation Visualization
slides.content:
$$\begin{bmatrix} x' \\ y' \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \cos\theta & -\sin\theta \\ \sin\theta & \cos\theta \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix}$$

Rotation by angle θ around the origin

slides.title: Homogeneous Coordinates
slides.content: Unified representation for all transformations

slides.title: Homogeneous Coordinates
slides.content:
Homogeneous Coordinates: Add an extra dimension to represent 2D points as 3D vectors.

$$(x, y) \rightarrow (x, y, 1)$$

Enables all transformations (including translation) as matrix multiplication.

knowledgeCheck.question: Why do we use homogeneous coordinates in computer graphics?
knowledgeCheck.answer: Homogeneous coordinates allow all geometric transformations, including translation, to be expressed as matrix multiplication. This enables combining multiple transformations into a single matrix.

slides.title: Affine Transformations
slides.content: Preserving parallel lines

slides.title: Affine Transformation Matrix
slides.content:
$$\begin{bmatrix} x' \\ y' \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} a & b & t_x \\ c & d & t_y \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

Combines rotation, scaling, shearing, and translation

slides.title: Transformation Hierarchy
slides.content: From rigid to projective: each level adds more degrees of freedom

slides.title: Transformation Composition
slides.content:
Matrix multiplication allows combining transformations:

$$T_{combined} = T_3 \cdot T_2 \cdot T_1$$

Order matters! Transformations are applied right-to-left.

knowledgeCheck.question: If you want to rotate an image around its center, what sequence of transformations is needed?
knowledgeCheck.answer: 1) Translate to move center to origin, 2) Rotate around origin, 3) Translate back to original position. The matrices are multiplied: T_back × R × T_to_origin

slides.title: Projective Transformations
slides.content: Homography and perspective

slides.title: Projective Transformation
slides.content:
Homography (8 DOF):

$$\begin{bmatrix} x' \\ y' \\ w \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} h_{11} & h_{12} & h_{13} \\ h_{21} & h_{22} & h_{23} \\ h_{31} & h_{32} & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

Final coordinates: $(x'/w, y'/w)$

slides.title: Perspective Correction
slides.content: Correcting perspective distortion in document scanning and photography

slides.title: Interpolation
slides.content: Resampling pixel values

slides.title: Interpolation Methods
slides.content:
Nearest Neighbor
Fast, blocky artifacts
Bilinear
Smooth, slight blur
Bicubic
High quality, slower
Lanczos
Best quality, slowest

slides.title: Interpolation Artifacts
slides.content: Trade-off: Speed vs. quality. Nearest neighbor for speed, bicubic/Lanczos for quality.

knowledgeCheck.question: When would you prefer nearest-neighbor over bicubic interpolation?
knowledgeCheck.answer: Nearest-neighbor is preferred for: 1) Real-time applications where speed is critical, 2) Pixel art where you want to preserve sharp edges, 3) Binary/label images where interpolated values are meaningless.

slides.title: Image Warping
slides.content: Non-linear transformations for artistic effects and correction

slides.title: Polar Transforms
slides.content:
Polar Transform: Convert from Cartesian to polar coordinates.

$$r = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}, \quad \theta = \arctan(y/x)$$

Useful for analyzing circular patterns and rotational symmetry.

slides.title: Image Registration
slides.content: Aligning images from different sources

slides.title: Registration Pipeline
slides.content:
Registration Steps:
  1. Feature detection
  2. Feature matching
  3. Transformation estimation
  4. Image warping

slides.title: Feature Matching for Registration
slides.content: Corresponding points are used to estimate the transformation

slides.title: Image Registration Applications
slides.content: Medical imaging, satellite imagery, panorama stitching

slides.title: Implementation
slides.content:
import cv2
import numpy as np

img = cv2.imread('image.jpg')
rows, cols = img.shape[:2]

# Rotation matrix (center, angle, scale)
M = cv2.getRotationMatrix2D((cols/2, rows/2), 45, 1.0)
rotated = cv2.warpAffine(img, M, (cols, rows))

# Perspective transform
pts1 = np.float32([[0,0], [300,0], [0,300], [300,300]])
pts2 = np.float32([[0,0], [300,0], [50,300], [250,300]])
H = cv2.getPerspectiveTransform(pts1, pts2)
warped = cv2.warpPerspective(img, H, (cols, rows))

slides.title: Summary
slides.content: Key Takeaways

slides.title: Key Takeaways
slides.content:
1. Basic transforms: Translation, rotation, scaling
  2. Homogeneous coordinates: Unified matrix representation
  3. Affine: Preserves parallel lines (6 DOF)
  4. Projective: Homography for perspective (8 DOF)
  5. Interpolation: Nearest, bilinear, bicubic - trade speed vs quality
  6. Registration: Feature detection → matching → transform → warp
